comment.author: 47173307@N00
comment._content: Fantastic

comment.author: 80413507@N08
comment._content: yes, some time late afternoon summertime?

comment.author: 37107521@N00
comment._content: fascinating detail ! and  to wander through the "large" version - is equally so - and yes I think that the stucture is (mens) screened and open air  toilets

comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content: Sadly, none of the buildings on City Quay (in this view) are still standing but I think I spot Stack A, the building that now houses CHQ, on the opposite bank which would place this photo close to the Prince's Street junction. The gap in the shadows along the street frontage could be Prince's Street.

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: Fantastic image Carol and a treat for young and old.  I suspect that the majority of the people at the bow of the QE are looking at something well out in the river and most of the group of children nearest the camera are barefoot!  As you wrote there is so much going on.  As a child I remember clambering over cargo's like this in Limerick docks where load were lifted in and out in nets on lines strung from spars fitted to the mats of the STEAM ships.  I'm not old enough to have seen sailing ships though my Dad told me all about them!

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/foxglove] Thanks for confirmation! The metalwork is really nice...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 41675580@N08
comment._content:
Once again NLI you have come up trumps!
What a brilliant old picture that is a pure delight to see here, many thanks for sharing.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/77199267@N03] Think you're right about Stack A, so have plopped in down just the other side of Prince's Street. Thank you!

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] Makes you wonder what was going on. Spectacular ship passing? Massive load being moved? A seal popping up? (Have seen that at this point myself)

comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content: The two Goods Sheds that stood on Customs House Quay can also be seen. They are on this OS Map maps.osi.ie/publicviewer/#V1,716591,734466,7,9

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] Looks like about the end of July or the middle of May around five o'clock. The sun's just south of west and about 30 degrees up. I guess the haze makes it look more like summer.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/8468254@N02] Will take your word for it!
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: It's not very precise. You could work it out exactly but that's more effore than I'm prepared to put in. What the sun app will primarily do is let you rule out a suggested date.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: 1889-1915, apparently: Queen_Elizabeth

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: The pissoir seems to have an unusual glazed brick interior, glowing TARDIS-like in the afternoon sun. Tentatively, because I am no expert on Dublin street lights, post 1903. See www.archiseek.com/forum/viewtopic.php?t=3968#p33958

comment.author: 77318933@N08
comment._content:
Question please:
The ship seems completely made of wood - didn't they convert to metals by that time? As far as I know in 1914, the warships in WWI were already made of metals. Or, was something for warships only to be made of metals?

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: The sv QE pictured is steel.

comment.author: 77318933@N08
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/8468254@N02] Really? hmm why the masts and sails then? didn't they use coal back then to power the engines?

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: Apparently not: www.clydesite.co.uk/clydebuilt/viewship.asp?id=12482

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: Presumably if you wanted to treck across half the globe, sail was more efficient because you didn't have to keep stopping to refuel.

comment.author: 77318933@N08
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/8468254@N02] aha!

comment.author: 77318933@N08
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/8468254@N02] Status: Went Missing After - 21/12/1915 <--- now this is an interesting line here! ... lost to a German U-Boat?

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: Possibly. They used to hang out around there. If the U-boad was sunk before it reported it or reached base, there'd be no surviving record. A lot of ships just sailed into Tuskar rock in bad weather though.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Interesting description of the 'Queen Elizabeth' on her maiden voyage to Sydney - SMH 24/3/1890 p.8 - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/13764363 (It's not often I get to show off Trove to you guys!) " ... every part of her is steel, hull, masts, and yards. ... " She looks like she has had a fresh paint job here, unlike this "ca.1905" photo - images.slsa.sa.gov.au/edwardes/17/PRG1373_17_87.htm

comment.author: 47044499@N03
comment._content: I'd love to know what happened to this lovely vessel.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Presumably the glazed tiles were easier to clean/hose down?

Am I being dim about the street lights? If one is in our photo, and they started to be removed between 1903 and 1910, then doesn't that make our photo pre-1903?
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/8468254@N02] Great info on the sv Queen Elizabeth, thanks!
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] We love Trove around here!

If ca. 1905 is accurate for the sv Queen Elizabeth, then that would imply a much earlier date for this one or a much later date (obviously before 1915)! Earlier before it became quite so maggoty looking (technical term) or later after an overhaul...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: I'd say earlier. There's not enough dents and warping in the hull for it to be more than a couple of years old. Although there's a bit near the prow that looks like they might have bashed off a bit of rust and repainted it.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] You are not being dim; just conserving energy. That link above is to the relevant part of the history of Dublin street lights, and there is more information above. It was the earlier lamps which were removed when the new Pigeon House came online. Here is the whole caboodle - www.archiseek.com/forum/viewtopic.php?f=49&t=3968 . These lamps look c.1910 to me. Sydney had similar styled ones in 1912. www.cityofsydney.nsw.gov.au/history/sydneystreets/Minding... I agree the ship looks almost new. Hmmm ...

comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content: The sharp angle on the quayside wall is confusing me - it's not reflected on the 25inch OS Map on the OSI website but I don't have an exact date for this map. It looks quite new and could give a clue to the date.

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: Looking at it again you can see the lady with the tray under her shawl in the foreground obviously doing a bit of dealing to the passersby and crews.  There is also the gentleman in the foreground with the Gladstone bag like the one that Lady Bracknell used when she deposited Ernest in the Railway Station!  Great detail in this shot indeed!

comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content: A short history of City Quay by Turtle Bunbury www.turtlebunbury.com/published/published_books/docklands...

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/77199267@N03] The survey date on that map is 1907 (1st June, but they all say that).

comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] I think it's made up of a composite of maps from the Ordnance Survey that took place between 1888 and 1913 so that doesn't really help us narrow the date range.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content:
That's what you think.

Mu ha ha ha!

comment.author: 59941010@N06
comment._content: Brilliant.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/77199267@N03] If the map is dated 1907, then that huge crane and its rail tracks are not marked. Other cranes are shown on the north bank of the Liffey. So this photo is after the map? Imagine the stage fright when standing in the pissoir and the crane goes over the top! [http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] Surely not Lady Bracknell who left the "hand-bag" at Victoria Station cloak-room (the Brighton Line) ?! www.readeasily.com/oscar-wilde/00196/001960012.php .

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/77199267@N03] To be a bit less evil and a bit more helpful, if you go the that map, hit Search, select the right-hand Historic button, enter DN018 and hit Search, the map will turn green, and you'll see you're looking at sheets DN018-11 and -12. In the search results, there is a scrollable list of DN018-1 to 16, all of which have a survey date of 1907.

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] You're quite right it does say handbag but any representations I have ever seen of it were a Gladstone just like the one in the mans hand.  Also it cannot have been Lady Bracknell as it was Miss Prism that left the "handbag" in the waiting room.  Anyway it brought Oscar into the discussion and that cannot be a bad thing;-)

comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] Ah! Thanks for that. I've been trying to figure that out for a while now. This map from 1885 roots.swilson.info/dublin1885/Dublin1885.html shows what could be a sharper kink in the quay wall which would suggest that the wall was straightened or smoother out prior to the 1907 survey. Also the 1885 map shows a ferry crossing the river at this point which might explain the crowd looking out at the river.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] Birlliant tip on map dating; Thanks!

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Where do you think the photographer is? From the look of the Quay wall, he must be in the rigging of the nearer ship!

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: Is that round thing not the edge of an air pipe in the top left? That would put him on top of a cabin or other superstructure on the boat in the foreground.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: I think the black at top left is just where a piece of the glass negative has broken off.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: Also a plausible theory. That accounts for how very black it is.

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/8468254@N02] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] When I looked at it I wondered if that was a pipe or ventilation stack as well but I think that as Lemur says it is very, very black and Nialls theory is probably right.  Note the way the spars are crossed on the QE?  They are slanted down to the side where the ship is moored.  If she was being loaded or unloaded you would imagine that they would be slanted in the opposite direction?  They would surely be in the way for those operations.

comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content: Some info on Liffey ferry crossings here www.census.nationalarchives.ie/exhibition/dublin/waters.html Still think this is a plausible explanation for the group of people staring towards the river.

comment.author: 18885703@N00
comment._content: we have a few extant examples of similar urinals in Bristol- perhaps this one, too, is the product of Walter Macfarlane of Glasgow... www.hevac-heritage.org/items_of_interest/public_health/st...

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/belvedere] Thanks. Certainly could be the work of Walter McFarlane, and that foundry's work has turned up here before...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: I've spent rather too much time browsing reports in Freeman's of the deliberations of the Public Health Committee of Dublin Corporation, especially their decisions to erect urinals in various locations. I drew a blank with this one on City Quay, but the time wasn't wasted, as I came across the wonderful circumlocution chalet de nécessité. It's the phrase I will use from now on, even though it originally referred to something even grander than this one.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Does your chalet de necessité have a movable boudoir? If not, why not?

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] I think I'd prefer a chalet de nécessité in my mobile boudoir.
